causal_chains.name: Cold Surge Onset → Regional Transport Chain
causal_chains.description: During cold surge onset, northeasterly winds bring polluted air masses from eastern China and the Red River Delta industrial region, causing approximately 30% increase in PM2.5 concentrations in Hanoi.

nodes.description: Strengthening of the Siberian High pressure system over Lake Baikal
Initiation of cold air outbreak with strong northeasterly winds
Change in air mass pathways to northeastern trajectories from China
Transport of pollutants from eastern China and Red River Delta industrial areas
Elevated PM2.5 concentrations at receptor site (Hanoi)

causal_links.mechanism: Pressure gradient drives cold air southward
Strong NE winds establish new air mass trajectories
HYSPLIT trajectories show transport from polluted upwind regions
Advection of regional pollution increases local PM2.5

supporting_evidence.quote: During cold surge onsets, long-range transport from China causes an average increase of ~30% in PM2.5 concentrations.
PM2.5 driven by cold surges from the ground level could travel up to 2000 km from northern to southern China within two days.
The most prominent surface feature of the winter monsoon is cold surges induced by strong northwesterly winds along the eastern flank of the Siberian high.

causal_chains.name: Cold Surge Persistence → Local Stagnation Chain
causal_chains.description: During cold surge persistence phase, anticyclonic conditions establish prolonged stagnation, trapping local emissions and causing approximately 40% increase in PM2.5 concentrations.

nodes.description: Sustained cold air mass over the region after initial surge
Establishment of high pressure system with subsiding air
Weak winds and stable atmospheric conditions
Limited horizontal and vertical mixing of pollutants
Build-up of locally emitted pollutants
Elevated PM2.5 concentrations from accumulated local emissions

causal_links.mechanism: Cold air mass establishes surface high pressure

supporting_evidence.quote: The stagnation of local pollution during the cold surges persistence causes an average increase of ~40% in level of PM2.5.
A dozen multi-day pollution episodes occur from October to February in Hanoi, Vietnam due to prolonged anticyclonic conditions established after the northeast monsoon surges.
Type I is caused by the arrival of the cold surge in GBK, which leads to the development of stagnant conditions favorable for haze formation.

causal_chains.name: Temperature Inversion → Vertical Mixing Suppression Chain
causal_chains.description: Cold surges establish temperature inversions (nighttime radiation or subsidence type) that suppress vertical mixing and trap pollutants in the boundary layer.

nodes.description: Dry phase (via inland China) or humid phase (via East China Sea)
NRTI (dry phase) or STI (humid phase) development
Reduction in mixing layer height below 1000m during hazy days
Inhibited vertical dispersion of pollutants
Concentration of PM2.5 in shallow boundary layer

causal_links.mechanism: Air mass origin determines inversion type
Trapped emissions accumulate in boundary layer

supporting_evidence.quote: WPEs are associated with nighttime radiation temperature inversions (NRTIs) in the dry phase and subsidence temperature inversions (STIs) in the humid phase.

BLH proved to be one of the key factors controlling air pollution in Hanoi. The lower BLH on the hazy days weakened the vertical mixing and was directly related to an increase in aerosol concentrations at the surface.
In NRTI periods, the pollution level is about two times higher at night than in daytime.

causal_chains.name: Post-Cold Surge Secondary Aerosol Formation Chain
causal_chains.description: Following cold surge passage, stagnant conditions and favorable meteorology promote secondary aerosol formation, leading to nighttime PM2.5 peaks.

nodes.description: Cold front passes through the region
Calm conditions following cold surge
Build-up of gaseous precursors (SO2, NOx, VOCs)
Gas-to-particle conversion under favorable conditions
Maximum PM2.5 concentrations occurring at night

causal_links.mechanism: Chemical reactions convert gases to particles
Secondary aerosols peak during nighttime cooling

supporting_evidence.quote: The PM2.5 peak, which often appeared at night after a cold surge, may be the result of secondary particle formation under stagnant conditions.
Daily levels of PM2.5 and CO increased several days after most cold surge events.
It has been found that air pollutant levels increased over the couple of days that followed a cold surge.

causal_chains.name: Monsoon Cycle Evolution Chain
causal_chains.description: Complete monsoon cycle showing pollution evolution from low during surge onset, rising to peak at mid-cycle, then declining before next surge.
causal_chains.pm25_impact: Lowest during surge → Peak at mid-cycle

nodes.description: Initial cold air intrusion with high winds
Strong winds disperse existing pollution
Lowest pollutant concentrations during surge
Anticyclonic conditions establish after surge
Gradual increase in pollutant levels
Maximum pollution at middle of monsoon cycle
Pollution decreases ahead of next cold surge

supporting_evidence.quote: The 24-h pollutant concentrations are lowest during cold surges; concurrently rise thereafter reaching the highest levels toward the middle of a monsoon cycle, then decline ahead of the next cold surge.
Each monsoon cycle usually proceeds through a dry phase and a humid phase as Asiatic continental cold air arrives in Hanoi through inland China then via the East China Sea.

causal_chains.name: Long-Range Transport Lower Troposphere Chain
causal_chains.description: During cold surges, high wind speeds enable PM2.5 transport up to 2000 km in the lower troposphere within two days, a distinct mechanism from upper troposphere transport.

nodes.description: Strong high pressure system over Siberia
High-speed winds (>20 m/s) along eastern flank of high
Cold air outbreak moving southward
PM2.5 carried at ground level by surge winds
Transport of 2000 km within 2 days
PM2.5 increase at downwind locations

causal_links.mechanism: Surge carries pollutants at surface level
High wind speed enables rapid transport before deposition

supporting_evidence.quote: PM2.5 driven by cold surges from the ground level could travel up to 2000 km from northern to southern China within two days.
Wind speed was found to be a major facilitator in transporting PM2.5 from Beijing to Xiamen.
This finding is a new long-range transport mechanism comparing to the well-established mechanism, with long-range transport more likely to occur in the upper troposphere than at lower levels.

primary_mechanisms.mechanism: Regional Transport during Cold Surge Onset
primary_mechanisms.description: Northeasterly winds during cold surge onset transport polluted air masses from eastern China and the Red River Delta to Hanoi, causing ~30% PM2.5 increase.

primary_mechanisms.mechanism: Local Stagnation during Cold Surge Persistence
primary_mechanisms.description: Anticyclonic conditions during cold surge persistence create stagnation that traps local emissions, causing ~40% PM2.5 increase.
Following cold surge passage, stagnant conditions promote secondary aerosol formation, leading to nighttime PM2.5 peaks exceeding 100 µg/m³.

temporal_pattern.description: Cold surge effects on PM2.5 follow a characteristic temporal pattern within each monsoon cycle (~4 days average).

key_intermediate_variables.role: Determines vertical mixing capacity; BLH < 1000m during hazy days
NRTI (dry phase) or STI (humid phase) suppress vertical mixing
High during surge (dispersion/transport), low during persistence (stagnation)
Determines upwind source regions and pollution loading

quality_assessment.source_diversity: 7 Tier-1 peer-reviewed sources from multiple research groups
quality_assessment.chain_validation: All chains supported by multiple independent sources with direct quotes
quality_assessment.saturation_evidence: Consistent mechanisms identified across all 7 sources; no new mechanisms emerging
